description.narrative: Olof Palmes Internationella Center (OPIC) har ansökt hos ambassaden om 15,9 MSEK för att under en treårsperiod genomföra projektet: "Participation, transparency and accountability in Albania 2016-2018". Insatsen syftar till att stärka kapaciteten och legitimiteten av civilsamhällsorganisationer och stödja aktiviteter som garanterar deltagandet i politiska processer samt ansvarsskyldighet av ansvarsbärare. Civilsamhällsorganisationer kommer stärka kvinno- och ungdomsgrupper i deras arbete för social rättvisa, uppmuntra aktivism och mobilisera medborgare i frågor som rör ansvarsskyldighet, transparens och arbetsrättigheter. Som tidigare projekt finansierade av Sida i Albanien, kommer OPIC vidarebefordra medel till albanska organisationer för att de i sin tur ska genomföra åtgärder på lokal och nationell nivå. Vidare kommer OPIC förse organisationerna med teknisk support, plattformer för utbildning och utbyte av kunskap som kommer uppmuntra nätverkande. Syftet är att stärka de lokala organisationerna och göra dem mer hållbara. Exempel på åtgärder av OPIC: samarbetsparter som kommer att stödjas är: - Analysera jämställdhetsaspekterna, främja och skydda kvinnors rättigheter i arbetsmarknaden genom informationssökning, uppmuntrande av ökad medvetenhet, kapacitetsbyggande aktiviteter, nätverkande, lobbyverksamhet och opinionsbildning. - Öka studenters medvetenhet om universitetens strukturella problem och stödja studenters mobilisering i form av universitetsföreningar. - Identifiera ungdomars behov och prioriteringar på landsbygdsområden i Fier genom frågeformulär, lobbyinitiativ för att ta itu med ungdomars behov och informera andra ungdomar om möjligheterna att delta i de beslutsfattande processerna.
The intervention is a continuation of cooperation with Olof Palme International Center in supporting local civil society organisations

To strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and support activities that ensure the participatory nature of political processes and the accountability of duty bearers. Civil society organisations will empower women and youth groups in their work towards social justice, encourage activism and mobilise citizens on issues related to accountability and transparency and labour rights.

description.narrative: The programme has achieved interesting results in the three areas of the programme: 1) Popular participation, 2) transparency and accountability and 3) labour rights. Examples of these achievements in relation to the capacity of the partners, the ability to mobilise citizens and to demand transparency and accountability from duty holders are presented below: - OPC support to strengthening the local democracy has enabled youth and women to mobilise citizens in advocating for increased transparency and accountability. Since the last local elections in 2016, the CSOs have sought to hold elected politicians accountable through regular monitoring of the implementation of 8 social contracts signed by candidates for mayors as commitments to address citizens’ concerns during their term. The level of implementation of the Social Contracts 2015 reached 60–65% by the end of 2018. This is less than desired, but yet, it has positively affected the life of the communities it targets and also increases the confidence among citizens that change is possible. - Four partner organisations of OPC contributed towards increased respect for labour rights, the new thematic area included in the programme in 2016. The progress made in this field during 2016 -2018 is satisfactory and promising to build on. OPC partners have acted as an independent critical voice for labour issues, as well as a supportive structure to strengthening existing unions and workers that want to organize collectively. Their work has started to have direct positive impact to the working conditions of the employees. However, the overall situation remains critical in relation to the implementation of workers ’rights. - As result of engagement, the issues that youth and women of rural areas face have become more visible and taken greater attention. Pressure on the duty bearers has increased. A very good result is seen in Fier, where New Epoch and youth sought for funds for reconstructing the sports fields in 6 schools of the administrative units of Topoje and Dermenas. The project was co-financed by the GIZ and Fier municipality, each providing 600 000 ALL and implemented through the cooperation with New Epoch. In Puka, the municipality established a working group to provide free technical support to rural families for registering their properties and benefit from funding schemes for farming – the latter was a demand strongly articulated by the women our partner worked with. - The Center for Labour Rights (CLR) has contributed to the vitalization of the trade union movement through supporting a newly established union in the sector of oil and gas, New Trade Union of Albanian Oil Workers-SRNSH (2017) and providing ongoing assistance in terms of organisation, structure and building capacities during 2018. - The establishment of the CLR Labour Academy serves to an increased awareness, knowledge and capacities of the union members on the labour rights, giving rise to essential changes in the vision of existing trade unions and inspiring the development of the new generation of trade unionists. This innovative approach on labour rights promotion and strengthening of capacities of trade union coming from a pool of experienced experts resulted to be a highly appreciated and needed service by the trade unions in Albania. Participants in the academy are representatives from unions or non-organised individuals representing sectors of health, education, shoe and garment, extractive sector and civil society. CLR provides continuing mentoring and assistance to these groups as a follow-up process of the academy. - OPC has supported the Gender Alliance for Development centre (GADC), to monitor and report abuse, discrimination and violations of the rights of women workers in the garment and footwear industry and advocate for better working conditions and the compliance with international labour standards. In the last three years of work, GADC has provided data and facts on the working conditions and increased interest and engagement from different stakeholders (CSOs, state institutions, media, donors and international institutions) on the situation for women in this industry. OPC has provided to partners hands on support and advice, specialised trainings, networking possibilities and support for fund raising which has been well received and effective for the work of the Albanian partner organisations.
